verses.text: After Ahab died, Moab rebelled against Israel.
verses.comment: This succinctly reflects the Hebrew phrase, which simply states Moab rebelled after Ahab's death.

verses.text: Ahaziah fell through the lattice in his upper room in Samaria and was injured. So he sent messengers, saying to them, 'Go, ask Baal-Zebub, the god of Ekron, if I will recover from this injury.'
verses.comment: 'Baal-Zebub' preserves the Hebrew term; Ekron is a Philistine city.

verses.text: But the angel of the Lord said to Elijah the Tishbite, 'Get up, go meet the messengers of the king of Samaria, and ask them: "Is it because there is no God in Israel that you are going to inquire of Baal-Zebub, the god of Ekron?"'
verses.comment: Preserves rhetorical question. 'Angel of the Lord' per usual rendering.

verses.text: 'Therefore, this is what the Lord says: "You will not get up from the bed you are lying on. You will surely die."' So Elijah left.
verses.comment: 'Surely die' is a literal rendering from the Hebrew, emphatic repetition.

verses.text: When the messengers returned to Ahaziah, he asked them, 'Why have you come back?'

They answered him, 'A man came up to meet us and said, "Go back to the king who sent you and say: 'This is what the Lord says: Is there no God in Israel, that you are sending messengers to inquire of Baal-Zebub, the god of Ekron? Therefore, you will not get up from the bed you are lying on. You will surely die.'"'
verses.comment: Direct repetition of verse 3-4 message; maintains rhetorical force.

verses.text: Ahaziah asked them, 'What kind of man was it who came to meet you and told you these words?'
verses.comment: Direct question as in Hebrew text.

verses.text: They answered, 'He was a man with a hairy garment and with a leather belt around his waist.' Ahaziah said, 'It is Elijah the Tishbite.'
verses.comment: 'Hairy garment' is literal; similar clothing description as John the Baptist (Matt. 3:4).

verses.text: Then the king sent a captain with his fifty men to Elijah. He went up to Elijah, who was sitting on top of a hill, and said, 'Man of God, the king says, "Come down!"'
verses.comment: 'Man of God' is a maintained designation for Elijah.

verses.text: Elijah answered the captain, 'If I am a man of God, may fire come down from heaven and consume you and your fifty men.' Then fire came down from heaven and consumed him and his fifty men.
verses.comment: Maintains conditional phrasing and narrative sequence.

verses.text: So the king sent another captain with his fifty men to Elijah. He said, 'Man of God, this is what the king says, "Come down at once!"'
Elijah answered, 'If I am a man of God, may fire come down from heaven and consume you and your fifty men.' And the fire of God came down from heaven and consumed him and his fifty.
verses.comment: 'Fire of God' is a literal rendering of Hebrew 'esh Elohim'.

verses.text: So the king sent a third captain with his fifty men. This captain went up, fell on his knees before Elijah, and pleaded with him, 'Man of God, please let my life and the lives of these fifty servants be precious in your sight.'
verses.comment: 'Be precious in your sight' is a literal phrase; maintains humility and desperation.

verses.text: 'See, fire has come down from heaven and consumed the first two captains and their groups of fifty, but now let my life be precious in your sight.'
verses.comment: Third captain makes his plea, referencing previous events.

verses.text: Then the angel of the Lord said to Elijah, 'Go down with him. Do not be afraid.' So he got up and went down with him to the king.
verses.comment: 'Do not be afraid' is a literal rendering of the reassurance.

verses.text: He said to the king, 'This is what the Lord says: "Because you have sent messengers to ask Baal-Zebub, the god of Ekron—is it because there is no God in Israel to seek his word?—therefore you will not get up from the bed you are lying on. You will surely die."'
verses.comment: Maintains emphasis and rhetorical question; direct speech.

verses.text: So Ahaziah died, just as the word of the Lord spoken by Elijah had declared. Because Ahaziah had no son, Joram became king in his place in the second year of Jehoram son of Jehoshaphat, king of Judah.
verses.comment: Chronological details conform to received chronology.

verses.text: The rest of the acts of Ahaziah that he did are written in the Book of the Chronicles of the Kings of Israel.
verses.comment: Standard closing formula in Kings; refers to lost historical record.
